Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Preface

This standard aims at setting out accounting rules for recognizing, measuring and disclosing the transactions of Musharaka financing that are carried out by Islamic banks and financial institutions. The standard also provides details of the juristic principles on which the development of the proposed accounting treatment is based. It also highlights the different accounting alternatives which have been considered and the justifications for the alternative chosen for the accounting treatment of Musharaka financing.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 1. Scope of the Standard

This standard shall apply to Musharaka financing transactions carried out by Islamic banks whether by means of a constant Musharaka or a diminishing Musharaka. This shall apply whether the Islamic bank finances its share in Musharaka capital exclusively out of its own funds, out of the pool of commingled funds comprising the Islamic bank’s own funds and unrestricted investment accounts or out of restricted investment accounts. Should the requirements of this standard contradict the Islamic bank’s charter or the laws and regulations of the country in which it operates, a disclosure should be made of the contradiction. This standard does not include Mudaraba, Participations, Zakah on Musharaka funds, and Accounting treatment of Musharaka transactions in the partner’s (client’s) books and the Musharaka records.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/1 Recognition of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka capital at the time of contracting

The Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka capital (cash or kind) shall be recognized when it is paid to the partner or made available to him on the account of the Musharaka. This share shall be presented in the Islamic bank’s books under a Musharaka financing account with (name of client) and it shall be included in the financial statements under the heading 'Musharaka Financing'.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/2 Measurement of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka capital at the time of contracting > 2/2/1 Cash measurement

The Islamic bank’s share in the Musharaka capital provided in cash shall be measured by the amount paid or made available to the partner on the account of the Musharaka.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/2 Measurement of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka capital at the time of contracting > 2/2/2 Kind measurement

The Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka capital provided in kind shall be measured at the fair value of the assets, and if the valuation results in a difference between fair value and book value, such difference shall be recognized as profit or loss to the Islamic bank itself.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/2 Measurement of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka capital at the time of contracting > 2/2/3 Expenses

Expenses of the contracting procedures shall not be considered as part of the Musharaka capital unless otherwise agreed by both parties.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/3 Measurement of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka capital after contracting at the end of a financial period > 2/3/1 Constant Musharaka

The Islamic bank’s share in the constant Musharaka capital shall be measured at the end of the financial period at historical cost.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/3 Measurement of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka capital after contracting at the end of a financial period > 2/3/2 Diminishing Musharaka

The Islamic bank’s share in the diminishing Musharaka shall be measured at historical cost after deducting the historical cost of any share transferred to the partner, recognizing any difference as profit or loss.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/3 Measurement of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka capital after contracting at the end of a financial period > 2/3/3 Liquidation before complete transfer

If the diminishing Musharaka is liquidated before complete transfer, the amount recovered shall be credited to the Islamic bank’s Musharaka financing account with recognition of any profit or loss.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/3 Measurement of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka capital after contracting at the end of a financial period > 2/3/4 Termination or liquidation

If the Musharaka is terminated or liquidated and the Islamic bank’s share remains unpaid, it shall be recognized as a receivable due from the partner.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/4 Recognition of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka profits or losses > 2/4/1 Profits or losses during a period

Profits or losses in respect of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka financing transactions that commence and end during a financial period shall be recognized at the time of liquidation.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/4 Recognition of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka profits or losses > 2/4/2 Constant Musharaka profits

In a constant Musharaka that continues for more than one financial period, the Islamic bank’s share of profits shall be recognized to the extent that the profits are being distributed; losses shall be recognized to the extent that such losses are being deducted from its share.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/4 Recognition of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka profits or losses > 2/4/3 Diminishing Musharaka profits

Item 2/4/2 shall apply to a diminishing Musharaka after considering the decline in the Islamic bank’s share.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/4 Recognition of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka profits or losses > 2/4/4 Unpaid profits

If the partner does not pay the Islamic bank its due share of profits, the due share shall be recognized as a receivable.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/4 Recognition of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka profits or losses > 2/4/5 Losses due to partner's misconduct

If losses are incurred due to the partner’s misconduct or negligence, the partner shall bear the Islamic bank’s share of such losses, recognized as a receivable.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/4 Recognition of the Islamic bank’s share in Musharaka profits or losses > 2/4/6 Provisions for doubtful receivables

The Islamic bank’s unpaid share shall be recorded in a Musharaka receivables account with provisions made if they are doubtful.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/5 Disclosure requirements > 2/5/1 Provision Disclosure

Disclosure should be made in financial statements if the Islamic bank has made during that period a provision for a loss of its capital in Musharaka transactions.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 2. Accounting Treatment of Musharaka Financing > 2/5 Disclosure requirements > 2/5/2 General Presentation and Disclosure

The disclosure requirements stated in Financial Accounting Standard No. (1) should be observed.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Statement of the Standard > 3. Effective Date

This Standard shall be effective for financial statements for fiscal periods beginning 1 Muharram 1418 A.H. or 1 January 1998 A.D.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 1

In its meeting No. (3) held in Tehran on 13 Jumada I, 1413 A.H., corresponding to 8 November 1992 A.D., the former Financial Accounting Standards Board decided to start with the preparation of the following standards: 1. Murabaha and Murabaha to the Purchase Orderer. 2. Musharaka Financing. 3. Mudaraba Financing.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 2

In February 1993, a list was compiled of consultants who could be assigned by the (former) Executive Committee for Planning and Follow-up to prepare the above three standards. The issue was submitted to the Committee in its meeting No. (28) held in Makkah during the period of 10-11 Ramadan 1413 A.H., corresponding to 3-4 March 1993 A.D., and a consultant was selected to carry out a study on the juristic and accounting aspects of the Musharaka financing standard.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 3

On May 25, 1993 the consultant was formally notified of his assignment to prepare the standard and its requirements. The preliminary study of the standard was discussed in the Committee meeting No. (31) held in Bahrain on 6 Rabi’ II, 1414 A.H., corresponding to 23 September 1993 A.D.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 4

The Committee members gave their comments and some details thereon and the consultant was asked to take them into consideration. The revised version of the juristic and accounting aspects of the study was prepared in Jumada II, 1414 A.H., corresponding to November 1993 A.D.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 5

The consultant was asked on 4 Rajab 1413 A.H., corresponding to 18 December 1993 A.D., to prepare a field survey plan of the standard comprising a questionnaire on the data to be collected, the countries in which the study will take place, and the number of Islamic banks to be covered by the study.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 6

The plan and the field study questionnaire were prepared in Sha’ban 1414 A.H., corresponding to January 1994 A.D., and were discussed by the Committee in its meeting No. (32) held in Makkah on 18 Ramadan 1414 A.H., corresponding to 28 February 1994 A.D. The Committee members and consultants were assigned to send the questionnaires to Islamic banks in the countries specified for each member.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 7

Responses to the field study questionnaire were received during the period from Dhul-Qa’dah 1414 A.H., to Rabi’ II, 1415 A.H., corresponding to April-September 1994 A.D., from the following Islamic banks: Bahrain Islamic Bank, Faysal Islamic Bank – Bahrain, Al Baraka Islamic Investment Bank – Bahrain, Tadamon Islamic Bank – Sudan, Omdurman National Bank – Sudan, Khartoum Bank – Sudan, Al Shmal Islamic Bank – Sudan, Faisal Islamic Bank – Egypt, International Islamic Bank for Investment & Development – Egypt, Egyptian Saudi Finance House, Qatar Islamic Bank, Al Rajhi Banking and Investment Corporation, Jordan Islamic Bank, Dubai Islamic Bank.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 8

A memo was presented to the (former) Financial Accounting Standards Board in its meeting No. (6) held in Bahrain on 16 Dhul-Qa’dah 1414 A.H., corresponding to 26 April 1994 A.D., comprising the preliminary suggestions for accounting treatments. The Board’s members commented on those suggestions.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 9

The consultant revised the draft of juristic and accounting aspects of the standard in light of the comments made in the Board meeting. The revised draft was issued in Muharram 1415 A.H., corresponding to June 1994 A.D.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 10

In its meeting No. (36) held in Cairo on 3-4 Rabi’ I, 1415 A.H., corresponding to 10-11 August 1994 A.D., the Committee discussed the draft of the accounting and juristic aspects of the standard and made comments and additions which were used as a basis for preparing a revised draft of the study.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 11

The revised draft was completed in Jumada I, 1415 A.H., corresponding to November 1994 A.D., and presented to the Committee in its meeting No. (38) held in Bahrain during the period of 25-27 Jumada II, 1415 A.H., corresponding to 27-29 December 1994 A.D.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 12

In that meeting, the consultant was asked to prepare an exposure draft of the standard in light of the alternatives agreed on by the Committee.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 13

The juristic study was submitted to the Shari’ah Committee which highlighted in its meeting held in Makkah during the period of 7-8 Ramadan 1415 A.H., corresponding to 6-7 February 1995 A.D., the need for reviewing and amending the juristic aspects by a Shari’ah consultant.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 14

The exposure draft of the standard was discussed by the Accounting Standards Committee of the Accounting and Auditing Standards Board in its meeting held in Bahrain during the period of 26-28 Muharram 1416 A.H., corresponding to 24-26 June 1995 A.D.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 15

The Accounting Standards Committee revised the exposure draft and referred it to the Shari’ah Committee which discussed it in its meeting held in Bahrain during the period of 1-2 Safar 1416 A.H., corresponding to 29-30 June 1995 A.D.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 16

The Accounting and Auditing Standards Board met on 24-26 Rabi’ II, 1416 A.H., corresponding to 19-21 September 1995 A.D., and discussed the exposure draft and made changes to it.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 17

The Board decided that the exposure draft should be distributed to specialists and interested parties to obtain their comments on the exposure draft in order to discuss them in a listening session.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 18

The listening session was held on 25-26 Rajab 1416 A.H., corresponding to 17-18 December 1995 A.D., in Bahrain. The listening session was attended by more than 40 participants representing central banks, Islamic banks, accounting firms, Shari’ah scholars, academics and others who are interested in this field.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 19

Members of the Accounting Standards Committee responded in the listening session to the written comments received prior to the listening session as well as the oral comments expressed in the sessions.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 20

The Accounting Standards Committee held a meeting on 20-21 Sha’ban 1416 A.H., corresponding to 12-13 January 1996 A.D., to discuss the comments made about the exposure draft. The Committee made the necessary amendments which it deemed necessary in light of the discussions that took place in the listening session.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (A) > Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 21

The Accounting and Auditing Standards Board adopted the proposed standard in its meeting No. (10) held on 14-16 Ramadan 1416 A.H., corresponding to 3-5 February 1996 A.D.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1. Definition of Musharaka in Fiqh (Jurisprudence)

It is the commingling of funds for the purpose of sharing in profit.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/1 Categories of Musharaka

Partnerships are of two types: Holding Partnership and Contract Partnership.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/1 Categories of Musharaka > 1/1/1 Al-Inan partnership

It is a contract between two or more persons with varied contributions sharing in profit or loss as agreed.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/1 Categories of Musharaka > 1/1/2 Al-Mufawada partnership

A partnership with equal contribution, work, responsibility, and liability for debts.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/1 Categories of Musharaka > 1/1/3 Al-A’mal partnership

A contract to accept work jointly and share profits from such work.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/1 Categories of Musharaka > 1/1/4 Al-Wujuh partnership

A partnership involving reputation to trade on credit, sharing profits or losses as per guarantees provided.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/2 Musharaka elements and conditions > 1/2/1 Musharaka elements

The elements of Musharaka are: Wording, contract parties, and subject matter (funding and work).

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/2 Musharaka elements and conditions > 1/2/2 Terms of Musharaka > 1/2/2/1 Wording

Any utterance expressing the purpose may form a Musharaka contract, orally or in writing.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/2 Musharaka elements and conditions > 1/2/2 Terms of Musharaka > 1/2/2/2 Contracting parties

Partners must be competent to give or receive power of attorney.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/2 Musharaka elements and conditions > 1/2/2 Terms of Musharaka > 1/2/2/3 Subject matter of the contract

Fund can be cash or tangible/intangible assets equivalent to cash. Work participation is a must.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/3 Musharaka rules > 1/3/1 Rules of capital

Capital must not be guaranteed, transfer based on fair value, and managed with care.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/3 Musharaka rules > 1/3/1 Rules of capital > a) Power of attorney and disposition of funds

Partners can dispose funds as agents of each other, not for personal use.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/3 Musharaka rules > 1/3/1 Rules of capital > b) Non-guarantee of capital

No partner can guarantee another's capital, liability exists only for negligence or misconduct.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/3 Musharaka rules > 1/3/2 Work rules

Partners act as agents, work scope should align with partnership objectives.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/3 Musharaka rules > 1/3/3 Rules of profit

Profit must be quantifiable and shared proportionately unless agreed otherwise.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/3 Musharaka rules > 1/3/3 Rules of profit > a) General rules of profit

Profit should be proportion of total profit without predetermined amounts.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/3 Musharaka rules > 1/3/3 Rules of profit > b) Rules of allocating profits among partners

Fuqaha differ; profit can be proportional to capital or based on contribution.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/3 Musharaka rules > 1/3/4 Rules applicable in case of loss

Loss shared as per capital shares, deferral permitted in ongoing concerns.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix B: Juristic Rules for Musharaka Financing Transactions > 1/3 Musharaka rules > 1/3/5 Rules of Musharaka termination

Terminated by partner's will, death, or loss of legal competence; agency-based.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (C) Reasons for the Standard

The Executive Committee for Planning and Follow-up (the Committee) has commissioned a number of consultants to conduct field studies to identify the objectives and standards of financial accounting and the role of governmental and private bodies in preparing accounting standards in countries in which Islamic banks operate. These field studies included the identification of standards that were badly needed and should be given priority by the Financial Accounting Standards Board. The survey revealed the need for early preparation of each of the following standards: a) Murabaha and Murabaha to the Purchase Orderer. b) Musharaka Financing. c) Mudaraba Financing. While preparing the previous Financial Accounting Statement No. (1): Objectives of Financial Accounting for Islamic Banks and Financial Institutions (Statement of Objectives), and Financial Accounting Statement No. (2) : Concept of Financial Accounting for Islamic Banks and Financial Institutions (Statement of Concepts), the consultants were asked to propose nine standards which were considered important and deserved to be given priority in preparation. The consultants were also asked to arrange the proposed standards in order of priority. The selection of the above three standards was based on the decision of the Standards Board in its third meeting held in Tehran on 13 Jumada I, 1413 A.H., corresponding to 8 November 1993 A.D., to give priority to the standards relating to financial instruments. The responses to the field study questionnaire which was conducted by the Accounting and Auditing Organization, showed that the average percentage of transactions in which Musharaka financing is used was 15%.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (D) Basis for Conclusions > Recognition and Measurement of the Islamic Bank's Share in Musharaka Capital at the Time of Contracting

The Musharaka capital is governed by a group of principles, the most significant of which are: The share of each partner should be known, specified and agreed as to its amount at the time of contracting, the share of the capital of each partner should be available at the time of contracting. This cannot be in the form of a debt on account in order to avoid deception, misunderstanding and inability to make use of the capital. If the capital is in the form of real or intangible assets, Shari’a principles require the valuation of the intangible assets by agreement of the partners, and the Islamic bank’s share in the Musharaka shall be measured at fair value at the time of contracting. The valuation can be conducted by experts or by the partners as agreed by the two parties.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (D) Basis for Conclusions > Reasons for Not Using Historical Cost

First: The use of the value agreed upon (fair value) by the two parties achieves one of the financial accounting objectives provided for in the Statement of Objectives. Second: The use of the fair value leads to the application of the representational faithfulness concept provided for in the Statement of Concepts.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (D) Basis for Conclusions > Measurement of the Islamic Bank's Share in Musharaka Capital After Contracting, at the End of the Financial Period

The Islamic bank’s share after contracting is measured at its historical cost because Shari’a rules of Musharaka requires the determination of capital and its maintenance up to the time of final settlement in order to determine profit. The latter is defined as the amount earned in excess of the initial Musharaka capital. This conforms with the accounting measurement attribute provided for in the Statement of Concepts.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (D) Basis for Conclusions > Recognition of the Islamic Bank's Share in the Profit or Loss of Musharaka

The standard distinguished between Musharaka financing transactions (constant or diminishing ownership) which end during a financial period, and those which continue for more than one financial period. In the first case, the profits or losses are recognized after liquidation. This is in conformity with the Shari’a principle stating: No profit shall be deemed due except after maintaining the capital; i.e., after liquidation which reveals an excess (profit) over the initial capital or shortage (loss) therefrom. In the second case, if the Musharaka financing transactions continue for more than one financial period, the Islamic bank’s share of profits for a financial period resulting from partial or final settlement shall be recognized to the extent that the profits are being distributed; recognition of the Islamic bank’s share of losses for any period is made to the extent that such losses are being deducted from its share of the Musharaka capital.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (E) Definitions > Musharaka

A form of partnership between the Islamic bank and its clients whereby each party contributes to the capital of partnership in equal or varying degrees to establish a new project or share in an existing one, and whereby each of the parties becomes an owner of the capital on a permanent or declining basis and shall have his due share of profits. However, losses are shared in proportion to the contributed capital. It is not permissible to stipulate otherwise.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (E) Definitions > Constant Musharaka

It is a Musharaka in which the partners’ shares in the capital remain constant throughout the period as specified in the contract.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (E) Definitions > Diminishing Musharaka

It is a Musharaka in which the Islamic bank agrees to transfer gradually to the other partner its (the Islamic bank’s) share in the Musharaka, so that the Islamic bank’s share declines and the other partner’s share increases until the latter becomes the sole proprietor of the venture.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (E) Definitions > Participation

It is a Musharaka in which the Islamic bank owns shares or units representing an equity stake in another firm’s capital.

Financial Accounting Standard No. (4): Musharaka Financing > Appendix (E) Definitions > Mudaraba

It is a partnership in profit between capital and work. It is conducted between investment accountholders as owners of capital and the Islamic bank as a Mudarib. The Islamic bank announces its willingness to accept the funds of investment amount holders, the sharing of profits being as agreed upon between the two parties, and the losses being borne by the owner of funds except if they were due to misconduct, negligence or violation of the conditions agreed upon by the Islamic bank. In the latter cases such losses would be borne by the Islamic bank. A Mudaraba contract may also be concluded between the Islamic bank, as a provider of capital on behalf of itself or on behalf of investment accountholders, and business owners and other craftsmen, including farmers, traders etc. A Mudaraba cannot include market operations undertaken for purely speculative purposes, which are a form of gambling.
